name: 1613_E. Crazy Robot
description:
There is a grid, consisting of n rows and m columns. Each cell of the grid is either free or blocked. One of the free cells contains a lab. All the cells beyond the borders of the grid are also blocked.

A crazy robot has escaped from this lab. It is currently in some free cell of the grid. You can send one of the following commands to the robot: "move right", "move down", "move left" or "move up". Each command means moving to a neighbouring cell in the corresponding direction.

However, as the robot is crazy, it will do anything except following the command. Upon receiving a command, it will choose a direction such that it differs from the one in command and the cell in that direction is not blocked. If there is such a direction, then it will move to a neighbouring cell in that direction. Otherwise, it will do nothing.

We want to get the robot to the lab to get it fixed. For each free cell, determine if the robot can be forced to reach the lab starting in this cell. That is, after each step of the robot a command can be sent to a robot such that no matter what different directions the robot chooses, it will end up in a lab.

Input

The first line contains a single integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 1000) — the number of testcases.

The first line of each testcase contains two integers n and m (1 ≤ n, m ≤ 10^6; n ⋅ m ≤ 10^6) — the number of rows and the number of columns in the grid.

The i-th of the next n lines provides a description of the i-th row of the grid. It consists of m elements of one of three types: 

  * '.' — the cell is free; 
  * '#' — the cell is blocked; 
  * 'L' — the cell contains a lab. 



The grid contains exactly one lab. The sum of n ⋅ m over all testcases doesn't exceed 10^6.

Output

For each testcase find the free cells that the robot can be forced to reach the lab from. Given the grid, replace the free cells (marked with a dot) with a plus sign ('+') for the cells that the robot can be forced to reach the lab from. Print the resulting grid.

Example

Input


4
3 3
...
.L.
...
4 5
#....
..##L
...#.
.....
1 1
L
1 9
....L..#.


Output


...
.L.
...
#++++
..##L
...#+
...++
L
++++L++#.

Note

In the first testcase there is no free cell that the robot can be forced to reach the lab from. Consider a corner cell. Given any direction, it will move to a neighbouring border grid that's not a corner. Now consider a non-corner free cell. No matter what direction you send to the robot, it can choose a different direction such that it ends up in a corner.

In the last testcase, you can keep sending the command that is opposite to the direction to the lab and the robot will have no choice other than move towards the lab.
prompt:
There is a grid made up of n rows and m columns, where each cell is either free or blocked, and one of the free cells contains a lab, with all the cells beyond the borders of the grid also being blocked. A crazy robot has escaped from this lab and is currently in some free cell of the grid, where you can send one of the following commands: "move right", "move down", "move left" or "move up", each representing moving to a neighbouring cell in the corresponding direction.

However, as the robot is crazy, it will do anything except following the command, and upon receiving it, it will choose a different direction such that it is not blocked, moving to a neighbouring cell if possible, or doing nothing otherwise. We want to get the robot to the lab to get it fixed, and for each free cell, determine if the robot can be compelled to reach the lab starting from this cell, ensuring that after each move of the robot, a command can be sent such that no matter what alternative directions it chooses, it will end up in the lab. Make sure to optimize the solution for large grids to handle up to 1000x1000 cells efficiently.

Input

The first line contains a single integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 1000) — the number of testcases.

The first line of each testcase contains two integers n and m (1 ≤ n, m ≤ 10^6; n ⋅ m ≤ 10^6) — the number of rows and the number of columns in the grid.

The i-th of the next n lines provides a description of the i-th row of the grid. It consists of m elements of one of three types: 

  * '.' — the cell is free; 
  * '#' — the cell is blocked; 
  * 'L' — the cell contains a lab. 



The grid contains exactly one lab. The sum of n ⋅ m over all testcases doesn't exceed 10^6.

Output

For each testcase find the free cells that the robot can be forced to reach the lab from. Given the grid, replace the free cells (marked with a dot) with a plus sign ('+') for the cells that the robot can be forced to reach the lab from. Print the resulting grid.

In the last testcase, you can keep sending the command that is opposite to the direction to the lab and the robot will have no choice other than move towards the lab.

A crazy robot has escaped from this lab and is currently in some free cell of the grid, where you can send one of the following commands: "move right", "move down", "move left" or "move up", each representing moving to a neighbouring cell in the corresponding direction.

However, as the robot is crazy, it will do anything except following the command, and upon receiving it, it will choose a different direction such that it is not blocked, moving to a neighbouring cell if possible, or doing nothing otherwise. We want to get the robot to the lab to get it fixed, and for each free cell, determine if the robot can be compelled to reach the lab starting from this cell, ensuring that after each move of the robot, a command can be sent such that no matter what alternative directions it chooses, it will end up in the lab. Make sure to optimize the solution for large grids to handle up to 1000x1000 cells efficiently.

Input

The first line contains a single integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 1000) — the number of testcases.

The first line of each testcase contains two integers n and m (1 ≤ n, m ≤ 10^6; n ⋅ m ≤ 10^6) — the number of rows and the number of columns in the grid.

The i-th of the next n lines provides a description of the i-th row of the grid. It consists of m elements of one of three types:

from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple
from collections import deque

def find_reachable_cells(t: int, test_cases: List[List[str]]) -> List[List[str]]:
    """Finds the free cells from which the robot can be forced to reach the lab.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[List[str]]): List of grids for each test case.

    Returns:
        List[List[str]]: Modified grids with reachable cells marked.
    """
    results = []

    for grid in test_cases:
        n = len(grid)
        m = len(grid[0])
        lab_position = None

        # Convert grid to a mutable list of lists
        grid = [list(row) for row in grid]

        # Find the lab position
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == 'L':
                    lab_position = (i, j)
                    break
            if lab_position:
                break

        # Perform BFS from the lab position
        if lab_position:
            queue = deque([lab_position])
            visited = set([lab_position])

            while queue:
                x, y = queue.popleft()

                # Check all four possible directions
                for dx, dy in [(-1, 0), (1, 0), (0, -1), (0, 1)]:
                    nx, ny = x + dx, y + dy

                    if 0 <= nx < n and 0 <= ny < m and (nx, ny) not in visited:
                        if grid[nx][ny] == '.':
                            # Check if the cell can be forced to reach the lab
                            free_neighbors = 0
                            for ddx, ddy in [(-1, 0), (1, 0), (0, -1), (0, 1)]:
                                nnx, nny = nx + ddx, ny + ddy
                                if 0 <= nnx < n and 0 <= nny < m and grid[nnx][nny] == '.':
                                    free_neighbors += 1

                            if free_neighbors <= 1:
                                grid[nx][ny] = '+'
                                queue.append((nx, ny))
                                visited.add((nx, ny))

        # Convert grid back to list of strings
        results.append([''.join(row) for row in grid])

    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    t = int(input().strip())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n, m = map(int, input().strip().split())
        grid = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
        test_cases.append(grid)

    # Call the function
    results = find_reachable_cells(t, test_cases)

    # Output interface
    for result in results:
        for line in result:
            print(line)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple
from collections import deque

def find_reachable_cells(t: int, test_cases: List[List[str]]) -> List[List[str]]:
    """Determine which free cells can lead the robot to the lab.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[List[str]]): List of grids for each test case.

    Returns:
        List[List[str]]: Modified grids with reachable cells marked.
    """
    def bfs_from_lab(grid: List[str], n: int, m: int) -> List[str]:
        """Perform BFS from the lab to mark reachable cells.

        Args:
            grid (List[str]): The grid for the current test case.
            n (int): Number of rows in the grid.
            m (int): Number of columns in the grid.

        Returns:
            List[str]: The grid with reachable cells marked.
        """
        # Find the lab position
        lab_position = None
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == 'L':
                    lab_position = (i, j)
                    break
            if lab_position:
                break

        # Directions for moving in the grid
        directions = [(-1, 0), (1, 0), (0, -1), (0, 1)]

        # Initialize the queue for BFS
        queue = deque([lab_position])
        visited = set([lab_position])

        # Convert grid to a list of lists for mutability
        grid = [list(row) for row in grid]

        while queue:
            x, y = queue.popleft()

            for dx, dy in directions:
                nx, ny = x + dx, y + dy

                if 0 <= nx < n and 0 <= ny < m and (nx, ny) not in visited:
                    if grid[nx][ny] == '.':
                        # Mark the cell as reachable
                        grid[nx][ny] = '+'
                        queue.append((nx, ny))
                        visited.add((nx, ny))

        # Convert grid back to list of strings
        return [''.join(row) for row in grid]

    results = []
    for grid in test_cases:
        n = len(grid)
        m = len(grid[0]) if n > 0 else 0
        results.append(bfs_from_lab(grid, n, m))

    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    t = int(input().strip())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n, m = map(int, input().strip().split())
        grid = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
        test_cases.append(grid)

    # Output interface
    result = find_reachable_cells(t, test_cases)
    for grid in result:
        for row in grid:
            print(row)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple
from collections import deque

def find_reachable_cells(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, int, List[str]]]) -> List[List[str]]:
    """Finds free cells from which the robot can be forced to reach the lab.

    Args:
        t: Number of test cases.
        test_cases: A list of tuples, each containing the grid dimensions and the grid itself.

    Returns:
        A list of grids with reachable free cells marked with '+'.
    """
    results = []

    for n, m, grid in test_cases:
        # Convert grid to a list of lists for easier manipulation
        grid = [list(row) for row in grid]
        
        # Find the lab position
        lab_position = None
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == 'L':
                    lab_position = (i, j)
                    break
            if lab_position:
                break
        
        # Directions for BFS traversal: up, down, left, right
        directions = [(-1, 0), (1, 0), (0, -1), (0, 1)]
        
        # BFS to find all reachable free cells
        queue = deque([lab_position])
        visited = set([lab_position])
        
        while queue:
            x, y = queue.popleft()
            
            for dx, dy in directions:
                nx, ny = x + dx, y + dy
                
                if 0 <= nx < n and 0 <= ny < m and (nx, ny) not in visited:
                    if grid[nx][ny] == '.':
                        # Check if the cell is reachable
                        free_neighbors = 0
                        for ddx, ddy in directions:
                            nnx, nny = nx + ddx, ny + ddy
                            if 0 <= nnx < n and 0 <= nny < m and grid[nnx][nny] == '.':
                                free_neighbors += 1
                        if free_neighbors <= 1:
                            grid[nx][ny] = '+'
                            queue.append((nx, ny))
                    visited.add((nx, ny))
        
        # Convert grid back to list of strings
        results.append([''.join(row) for row in grid])
    
    return results

def main():
    """Main function to handle input and output."""
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n, m = map(int, input().split())
        grid = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
        test_cases.append((n, m, grid))
    
    results = find_reachable_cells(t, test_cases)
    for result in results:
        for row in result:
            print(row)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple
from collections import deque

def find_reachable_cells(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, int, List[str]]]) -> List[List[str]]:
    """Find free cells from which the robot can be forced to reach the lab.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[Tuple[int, int, List[str]]]): List of test cases, each containing grid dimensions and grid layout.

    Returns:
        List[List[str]]: Modified grids with reachable cells marked.
    """
    def bfs(n: int, m: int, grid: List[str]) -> List[str]:
        """Perform BFS to find reachable cells from the lab.

        Args:
            n (int): Number of rows in the grid.
            m (int): Number of columns in the grid.
            grid (List[str]): Grid layout.

        Returns:
            List[str]: Modified grid with reachable cells marked.
        """
        directions = [(0, 1), (1, 0), (0, -1), (-1, 0)]
        lab_position = None
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == 'L':
                    lab_position = (i, j)
                    break
            if lab_position:
                break

        reachable = [[False] * m for _ in range(n)]
        queue = deque([lab_position])
        reachable[lab_position[0]][lab_position[1]] = True

        while queue:
            x, y = queue.popleft()
            for dx, dy in directions:
                nx, ny = x + dx, y + dy
                if 0 <= nx < n and 0 <= ny < m and grid[nx][ny] == '.' and not reachable[nx][ny]:
                    # Check if the cell is a corner or has only one free neighbor
                    free_neighbors = 0
                    for ddx, ddy in directions:
                        nnx, nny = nx + ddx, ny + ddy
                        if 0 <= nnx < n and 0 <= nny < m and grid[nnx][nny] == '.':
                            free_neighbors += 1
                    if free_neighbors <= 1:
                        reachable[nx][ny] = True
                        queue.append((nx, ny))

        # Modify the grid based on reachable cells
        modified_grid = []
        for i in range(n):
            row = []
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == '.' and reachable[i][j]:
                    row.append('+')
                else:
                    row.append(grid[i][j])
            modified_grid.append(''.join(row))
        
        return modified_grid

    results = []
    for n, m, grid in test_cases:
        results.append(bfs(n, m, grid))
    
    return results

# Input interface
t = int(input())
test_cases = []
for _ in range(t):
    n, m = map(int, input().split())
    grid = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
    test_cases.append((n, m, grid))

# Call the function
result = find_reachable_cells(t, test_cases)

# Output interface
for grid in result:
    for row in grid:
        print(row)
from typing import List
## main.py
from typing import List, Tuple
from collections import deque

def find_reachable_cells(t: int, test_cases: List[List[str]]) -> List[List[str]]:
    """Find free cells from which the robot can be forced to reach the lab.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[List[str]]): List of grids representing each test case.

    Returns:
        List[List[str]]: List of processed grids with reachable cells marked.
    """
    def bfs(grid: List[str], n: int, m: int, lab_pos: Tuple[int, int]) -> List[str]:
        """Perform BFS to find reachable cells from the lab.

        Args:
            grid (List[str]): The grid of the current test case.
            n (int): Number of rows in the grid.
            m (int): Number of columns in the grid.
            lab_pos (Tuple[int, int]): Position of the lab in the grid.

        Returns:
            List[str]: The grid with reachable cells marked.
        """
        directions = [(-1, 0), (1, 0), (0, -1), (0, 1)]
        queue = deque([lab_pos])
        visited = set([lab_pos])
        reachable_grid = [list(row) for row in grid]

        while queue:
            x, y = queue.popleft()
            for dx, dy in directions:
                nx, ny = x + dx, y + dy
                if 0 <= nx < n and 0 <= ny < m and (nx, ny) not in visited:
                    if grid[nx][ny] == '.':
                        # Check if the cell is surrounded by blocked cells
                        free_neighbors = 0
                        for ddx, ddy in directions:
                            nnx, nny = nx + ddx, ny + ddy
                            if 0 <= nnx < n and 0 <= nny < m and grid[nnx][nny] == '.':
                                free_neighbors += 1
                        if free_neighbors <= 1:
                            reachable_grid[nx][ny] = '+'
                            queue.append((nx, ny))
                    visited.add((nx, ny))

        return [''.join(row) for row in reachable_grid]

    result = []
    for grid in test_cases:
        n = len(grid)
        m = len(grid[0])
        lab_pos = None

        # Find the lab position
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == 'L':
                    lab_pos = (i, j)
                    break
            if lab_pos:
                break

        # Process the grid using BFS
        processed_grid = bfs(grid, n, m, lab_pos)
        result.append(processed_grid)

    return result

# Input interface

test_cases = []
for _ in range(t):
    n, m = map(int, input().split())
    grid = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
    test_cases.append(grid)

# Call the function
result = find_reachable_cells(t, test_cases)

# Output interface
for grid in result:
    for row in grid:
        print(row)
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple
from collections import deque

def find_reachable_cells(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, int, List[str]]]) -> List[List[str]]:
    """Determine which free cells can reach the lab in each test case grid.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[Tuple[int, int, List[str]]]): List of test cases, each containing:
            - n (int): Number of rows in the grid.
            - m (int): Number of columns in the grid.
            - grid (List[str]): The grid itself, represented as a list of strings.

    Returns:
        List[List[str]]: A list of grids with reachable cells marked with '+'.
    """
    results = []

    for n, m, grid in test_cases:
        # Convert grid to a mutable list of lists
        grid = [list(row) for row in grid]
        
        # Find the lab position
        lab_position = None
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == 'L':
                    lab_position = (i, j)
                    break
            if lab_position:
                break

        # Directions for moving in the grid
        directions = [(-1, 0), (1, 0), (0, -1), (0, 1)]

        # BFS to find all reachable cells from the lab
        queue = deque([lab_position])
        reachable = set([lab_position])

        while queue:
            x, y = queue.popleft()

            for dx, dy in directions:
                nx, ny = x + dx, y + dy

                if 0 <= nx < n and 0 <= ny < m and grid[nx][ny] == '.':
                    # Check if the cell can be forced to move towards the lab
                    free_directions = 0
                    for ddx, ddy in directions:
                        nnx, nny = nx + ddx, ny + ddy
                        if 0 <= nnx < n and 0 <= nny < m and grid[nnx][nny] == '.':
                            free_directions += 1

                    # If only one free direction, it can be forced towards the lab
                    if free_directions <= 1:
                        grid[nx][ny] = '+'
                        reachable.add((nx, ny))
                        queue.append((nx, ny))

        # Convert grid back to list of strings
        result_grid = [''.join(row) for row in grid]
        results.append(result_grid)

    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n, m = map(int, input().split())
        grid = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
        test_cases.append((n, m, grid))

    # Call the function and print the result
    results = find_reachable_cells(t, test_cases)
    for result in results:
        for line in result:
            print(line)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py
from collections import deque
from typing import List

def process_grid(n: int, m: int, grid: List[List[str]]) -> List[List[str]]:
    """Process the grid to determine which free cells can lead the robot to the lab.

    Args:
        n (int): Number of rows in the grid.
        m (int): Number of columns in the grid.
        grid (List[List[str]]): The grid representation with free cells, blocked cells, and a lab.

    Returns:
        List[List[str]]: The processed grid with reachable free cells marked with '+'.
    """
    # Directions for BFS traversal: right, down, left, up
    directions = [(0, 1), (1, 0), (0, -1), (-1, 0)]
    
    # Find the lab position
    lab_position = None
    for i in range(n):
        for j in range(m):
            if grid[i][j] == 'L':
                lab_position = (i, j)
                break
        if lab_position:
            break
    
    # Initialize BFS queue and visited set
    queue = deque([lab_position])
    visited = set([lab_position])
    
    # Perform BFS from the lab
    while queue:
        x, y = queue.popleft()
        
        for dx, dy in directions:
            nx, ny = x + dx, y + dy
            
            if 0 <= nx < n and 0 <= ny < m and (nx, ny) not in visited:
                if grid[nx][ny] == '.':
                    # Check if the cell can be forced to reach the lab
                    free_neighbors = 0
                    for ddx, ddy in directions:
                        nnx, nny = nx + ddx, ny + ddy
                        if 0 <= nnx < n and 0 <= nny < m and grid[nnx][nny] == '.':
                            free_neighbors += 1
                    
                    # If the cell has at most one free neighbor, it can be forced to reach the lab
                    if free_neighbors <= 1:
                        grid[nx][ny] = '+'
                        queue.append((nx, ny))
                
                visited.add((nx, ny))
    
    return grid

def main():
    """Main function to read input, process each test case, and output the result."""
    # Read number of test cases
    t = int(input())
    
    for _ in range(t):
        # Read grid dimensions
        n, m = map(int, input().split())
        
        # Read grid
        grid = [list(input().strip()) for _ in range(n)]
        
        # Process the grid to determine reachable cells
        result_grid = process_grid(n, m, grid)
        
        # Output the result grid
        for row in result_grid:
            print(''.join(row))

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple
from collections import deque

def find_reachable_cells(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, int, List[str]]]) -> List[List[str]]:
    """Finds free cells from which the robot can be compelled to reach the lab.

    Args:
        t: Number of test cases.
        test_cases: A list of tuples, each containing the grid dimensions and the grid itself.

    Returns:
        A list of grids with reachable cells marked with '+'.
    """
    def bfs(n: int, m: int, grid: List[str]) -> List[str]:
        """Performs BFS to find reachable cells from the lab.

        Args:
            n: Number of rows in the grid.
            m: Number of columns in the grid.
            grid: The grid representation.

        Returns:
            The modified grid with reachable cells marked.
        """
        directions = [(-1, 0), (1, 0), (0, -1), (0, 1)]
        visited = set()
        queue = deque()
        lab_position = None

        # Find the lab position and initialize BFS
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == 'L':
                    lab_position = (i, j)
                    queue.append(lab_position)
                    visited.add(lab_position)
                    break
            if lab_position:
                break

        # BFS to mark reachable cells
        while queue:
            x, y = queue.popleft()
            for dx, dy in directions:
                nx, ny = x + dx, y + dy
                if 0 <= nx < n and 0 <= ny < m and (nx, ny) not in visited and grid[nx][ny] == '.':
                    # Check if the cell can be forced to reach the lab
                    free_neighbors = 0
                    for ddx, ddy in directions:
                        nnx, nny = nx + ddx, ny + ddy
                        if 0 <= nnx < n and 0 <= nny < m and grid[nnx][nny] == '.':
                            free_neighbors += 1
                    if free_neighbors <= 1:
                        grid[nx] = grid[nx][:ny] + '+' + grid[nx][ny+1:]
                        queue.append((nx, ny))
                    visited.add((nx, ny))

        return grid

    result = []
    for n, m, grid in test_cases:
        modified_grid = bfs(n, m, grid)
        result.append(modified_grid)

    return result

# Input interface
t = int(input())
test_cases = []
for _ in range(t):
    n, m = map(int, input().split())
    grid = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
    test_cases.append((n, m, grid))

# Output interface
result = find_reachable_cells(t, test_cases)
for grid in result:
    for row in grid:
        print(row)
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple
from collections import deque

def find_reachable_cells(t: int, test_cases: List[List[str]]) -> List[List[str]]:
    """Finds the free cells from which the robot can be forced to reach the lab.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[List[str]]): List of grids for each test case.

    Returns:
        List[List[str]]: Modified grids with reachable cells marked.
    """
    results = []

    for grid in test_cases:
        n = len(grid)
        m = len(grid[0])
        lab_position = None

        # Find the lab position
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == 'L':
                    lab_position = (i, j)
                    break
            if lab_position:
                break

        # Initialize BFS
        queue = deque([lab_position])
        reachable = [[False] * m for _ in range(n)]
        reachable[lab_position[0]][lab_position[1]] = True

        # Directions for BFS: right, down, left, up
        directions = [(0, 1), (1, 0), (0, -1), (-1, 0)]

        # Perform BFS to find all reachable cells
        while queue:
            x, y = queue.popleft()

            for dx, dy in directions:
                nx, ny = x + dx, y + dy

                if 0 <= nx < n and 0 <= ny < m and grid[nx][ny] == '.' and not reachable[nx][ny]:
                    # Check if the cell is a dead-end or not
                    free_neighbors = 0
                    for ddx, ddy in directions:
                        nnx, nny = nx + ddx, ny + ddy
                        if 0 <= nnx < n and 0 <= nny < m and grid[nnx][nny] == '.':
                            free_neighbors += 1

                    # If the cell has at most one free neighbor, it's a dead-end
                    if free_neighbors <= 1:
                        reachable[nx][ny] = True
                        queue.append((nx, ny))

        # Construct the result grid
        result_grid = []
        for i in range(n):
            row = []
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == '.' and reachable[i][j]:
                    row.append('+')
                else:
                    row.append(grid[i][j])
            result_grid.append(''.join(row))

        results.append(result_grid)

    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n, m = map(int, input().split())
        grid = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
        test_cases.append(grid)

    # Call the function and print the result
    results = find_reachable_cells(t, test_cases)
    for result in results:
        for line in result:
            print(line)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple
from collections import deque

def find_reachable_cells(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, int, List[str]]]) -> List[List[str]]:
    """Find free cells from which the robot can be compelled to reach the lab.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[Tuple[int, int, List[str]]]): List of test cases, each containing grid dimensions and grid data.

    Returns:
        List[List[str]]: List of processed grids with reachable cells marked.
    """
    def bfs(n: int, m: int, grid: List[str], lab_pos: Tuple[int, int]) -> List[str]:
        """Perform BFS to find all reachable cells from the lab.

        Args:
            n (int): Number of rows in the grid.
            m (int): Number of columns in the grid.
            grid (List[str]): The grid representation.
            lab_pos (Tuple[int, int]): Position of the lab in the grid.

        Returns:
            List[str]: The grid with reachable cells marked.
        """
        directions = [(-1, 0), (1, 0), (0, -1), (0, 1)]
        queue = deque([lab_pos])
        visited = set([lab_pos])
        result_grid = [list(row) for row in grid]

        while queue:
            x, y = queue.popleft()
            for dx, dy in directions:
                nx, ny = x + dx, y + dy
                if 0 <= nx < n and 0 <= ny < m and (nx, ny) not in visited:
                    if grid[nx][ny] == '.':
                        # Check if the cell can be forced to reach the lab
                        free_neighbors = 0
                        for ddx, ddy in directions:
                            nnx, nny = nx + ddx, ny + ddy
                            if 0 <= nnx < n and 0 <= nny < m and grid[nnx][nny] == '.':
                                free_neighbors += 1
                        if free_neighbors <= 1:
                            result_grid[nx][ny] = '+'
                            queue.append((nx, ny))
                    visited.add((nx, ny))

        return [''.join(row) for row in result_grid]

    results = []
    for n, m, grid in test_cases:
        lab_pos = None
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == 'L':
                    lab_pos = (i, j)
                    break
            if lab_pos:
                break
        processed_grid = bfs(n, m, grid, lab_pos)
        results.append(processed_grid)

    return results

# Input interface
t = int(input())
test_cases = []
for _ in range(t):
    n, m = map(int, input().split())
    grid = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
    test_cases.append((n, m, grid))

# Output interface
result = find_reachable_cells(t, test_cases)
for grid in result:
    for row in grid:
        print(row)

examples:
Input

The first line contains a single integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 1000) — the number of testcases.

The first line of each testcase contains two integers n and m (1 ≤ n, m ≤ 10^6; n ⋅ m ≤ 10^6) — the number of rows and the number of columns in the grid.

The i-th of the next n lines provides a description of the i-th row of the grid. It consists of m elements of one of three types: 

  * '.' — the cell is free; 
  * '#' — the cell is blocked; 
  * 'L' — the cell contains a lab. 



The grid contains exactly one lab. The sum of n ⋅ m over all testcases doesn't exceed 10^6.

Output

For each testcase find the free cells that the robot can be forced to reach the lab from. Given the grid, replace the free cells (marked with a dot) with a plus sign ('+') for the cells that the robot can be forced to reach the lab from. Print the resulting grid.

Example

Input


4
3 3
...
.L.
...
4 5
#....
..##L
...#.
.....
1 1
L
1 9
....L..#.


Output


...
.L.
...
#++++
..##L
...#+
...++
L
++++L++#.

Note

In the first testcase there is no free cell that the robot can be forced to reach the lab from. Consider a corner cell. Given any direction, it will move to a neighbouring border grid that's not a corner. Now consider a non-corner free cell. No matter what direction you send to the robot, it can choose a different direction such that it ends up in a corner.

In the last testcase, you can keep sending the command that is opposite to the direction to the lab and the robot will have no choice other than move towards the lab.
